column2: HAMILTON WRIGHT MABIE
column3: HAMILTON WRIGHT MABIE

column2: Chevy Chace
column3: Chevy Chace

column2: God prosper long our noble king, Our liffes and safetyes all; A woefull hunting once there did In Chevy-Chace befall.
column3: God prosper long our noble king, Our liffes and safetyes all; A woefull hunting once there did In Chevy Chace befall.

column2: To drive the deere with hound and horne, Erle Percy took his way; The child may rue that is unborne The hunting of that day.
column3: To drive the deere with hound and horne, Erle Percy took his way; The child may rue that is unborne The hunting of that day.

column2: The stout Erle of Northumberland A vow to God did make, His pleasure in the Scottish woods Three summers days to take;
column3: The stout Erle of Northumberland A vow to God did make, His pleasure in the Scottish woods Three summers days to take;

column2: The cheefest harts in Chevy-Chace To kill and beare away: These tydings to Erle Douglas came, In Scotland where he lay.
column3: The cheefest harts in Chevy Chace To kill and beare away: These tydings to Erle Douglas came, In Scotland where he lay.

column2: Who sent Erie Percy present word, He wold prevent his sport; The English Erle not fearing that, Did to the woods resort,
column3: Who sent Erie Percy present word, He wold prevent his sport; The English Erle not fearing that, Did to the woods resort,

column2: With fifteen hundred bow-men bold, All chosen men of might, Who knew full well in time of neede To ayme their shafts arright.
column3: With fifteen hundred bow men bold, All chosen men of might, Who knew full well in time of neede To a y m e their shafts arright.

column2: The gallant greyhounds swiftly ran, To chase the fallow deere; On Munday they began to hunt, Ere day-light did appeare;
column3: The gallant greyhounds swiftly ran, To chase the fallow deere; On Munday they began to hunt, Ere day light did appeare;

column2: And long before high noone they had An hundred fat buckes slaine; Then having din'd, the drovyers went To rouze the deare againe.
column3: And long before high noone they had An hundred fat buckes slaine; Then having din'd, the drovyers went To rouze the deare againe.

column2: The bow-men mustered on the hills, Well able to endure; Theire backsides all, with speciall care, That day were guarded sure.
column3: The bow men mustered on the hills, Well able to endure; Theire backsides all, with speciall care, That day were guarded sure.

column2: The hounds ran swiftly through the woods, The nimble deere to take, That with their cryes the hills and dales An eccho shrill did make.
column3: The hounds ran swiftly through the woods, The nimble deere to take, That with their cryes the hills and dales An e c c h o shrill did make.

column2: Lord Percy to the quarry went, To view the tender deere; Quoth he, "Erle Douglas promised This day to meet me heere;
column3: Lord Percy to the quarry went, To view the tender deere; Quoth he, "Erle Douglas promised This day to meet me heere;

column2: But if I thought he wold not come, Noe longer wold I stay. With that, a brave younge gentleman Thus to the Erle did say:
column3: But if I thought he wold not come, Noe longer wold I stay. With that, a brave younge gentleman Thus to the Erle did say:

column2: Loe, yonder doth Erle Douglas come, His men in armour bright; Full twenty hundred Scottish speres, All marching in our sight.	Loe, yonder doth Erle Douglas come, His men in armour bright; Full twenty hundred Scottish speres, All marching in our sight.
column3: true

column2: All men of pleasant Tivydale, Fast by the river Tweede: "O cease your sport," Erle Percy said, "And take your bowes with speede.
column3: All men of pleasant Tivydale, Fast by the river Tweede: "O cease your sport," Erle Percy said, "And take your bowes with speede.

column2: And now with me, my countrymen, Your courage forth advance; For never was there champion yett In Scotland or in France,	And now with me, my countrymen, Your courage forth advance; For never was there champion yett In Scotland or in France,
column3: true

column2: That ever did on horsebacke come, But, if my hap it were, I durst encounter man for man, With him to breake a spere.
column3: That ever did on horsebacke come, But, if my hap it were, I durst encounter man for man, With him to breake a spere.

column2: Erle Douglas on his milke-white steede, Most like a baron bold, Rode formost of his company, Whose armour shone like gold.
column3: Erle Douglas on his milke white steede, Most like a baron bold, Rode formost of his company, Whose armour shone like gold.

column2: Show me, sayd hee, "whose men you bee, That hunt soe boldly heere, That, without my consent, doe chase And kill my fallow-deere."
column3: Show me, sayd hee, "whose men you bee, That hunt s o e boldly heere, That, without my consent, doe chase And kill my fallow deere."

column2: The man that first did answer make Was noble Percy hee; Who sayd, "Wee list not to declare, Nor shew whose men wee bee.
column3: The man that first did answer make Was noble Percy hee; Who sayd, "Wee list not to declare, Nor shew whose men wee bee.

column2: Yet will wee spend our deerest blood, Thy cheefest harts to slay; Then Douglas swore a solempne oathe, And thus in rage did say;
column3: Yet will wee spend our deerest blood, Thy cheefest harts to slay; Then Douglas swore a solempne oathe, And thus in rage did say;

column2: Ere thus I will out-braved bee, One of us two shall dye: I know thee well, an erle thou art; Lord Percy, soe am I.	Ere thus I will out braved bee, One of us two shall dye: I know thee well, an erle thou art; Lord Percy, s o e am i
column3: false

column2: But trust me, Percy, pittye it were, And great offence, to kill Any of these our guiltlesse men, For they have done no ill.	But trust me, Percy, pittye it were, And great offence, to kill Any of these our guiltlesse men, For they have done no ill.
column3: true

column2: Let thou and I the battell trye, And set our men aside. "Accurst bee he," Erle Percy sayd, "By whome this is denyed."
column3: Let thou and I the battell trye, And set our men aside. "Accurst bee he," Erle Percy sayd, "By whome this is denyed."

column2: Then stept a gallant squier forth, Witherington was his name, Who said, "I wold not have it told To Henry our king for shame,
column3: Then stept a gallant squier forth, Witherington was his name, Who said, "I wold not have it told To Henry our king for shame,

column2: That ere my captaine fought on foote, And I stood looking on: You bee two erles, sayd Witherington, "And I a squier alone.
column3: That ere my captaine fought on foote, And I stood looking on: You bee two erles, sayd Witherington, "And I a squier alone.

column2: Ile doe the best that doe I may, While I have power to stand; While I have power to weeld my sword, Ile fight with hart and hand.
column3: Ile doe the best that doe I may, While I have power to stand; While I have power to weeld my sword, Ile fight with hart and hand.

column2: Our English archers bent their bowes, Their harts were good and trew; Att the first flight of arrowes sent, Full four-score Scots they slew.
column3: Our English archers bent their bowes, Their harts were good and trew; Att the first flight of arrowes sent, Full four score Scots they slew.

column2: [Yet bides Earl Douglas on the bent, As Chieftain stout and good, As valiant Captain, all unmov'd The shock he firmly stood.
column3: [Yet bides Earl Douglas on the bent, As Chieftain stout and good, As valiant Captain, all unmov'd The shock he firmly stood.

column2: His host he parted had in three, As Leader ware and try'd, And soon his spearmen on their foes Bare down on every side.
column3: His host he parted had in three, As Leader ware and try'd, And soon his spearmen on their foes Bare down on every side.

column2: Throughout the English archery They dealt full many a wound; But still our valiant Englishmen All firmly kept their ground.
column3: Throughout the English archery They dealt full many a wound; But still our valiant Englishmen All firmly kept their ground.

column2: And throwing strait their bows away, They grasp'd their swords so bright: And now sharp blows, a heavy shower, On shields and helmets light.]
column3: And throwing strait their bows away, They grasp'd their swords so bright: And now sharp blows, a heavy shower, On shields and helmets light.]

column2: They clos'd full fast on everye side, Noe slacknes there was found; And many a gallant gentleman Lay gasping on the ground.
column3: They clos'd full fast on everye side, Noe slacknes there was found; And many a gallant gentleman Lay gasping on the ground.

column2: O Christ! it was a griefe to see, And likewise for to heare, The cries of men lying in their gore, And scattered here and there.
column3: O Christ! it was a griefe to see, And likewise for to heare, The cries of men lying in their gore, And scattered here and there.

column2: At last these two stout erles did meet, Like captaines of great might; Like lyons wood they layd on lode, And made a cruell fight.
column3: At last these two stout erles did meet, Like captaines of great might; Like lyons wood they layd on lode, And made a cruell fight.

column2: They fought, untill they both did sweat, With swords of tempered steele; Until the blood, like drops of rain, They trickling downe did feele.
column3: They fought, untill they both did sweat, With swords of tempered steele; Until the blood, like drops of rain, They trickling downe did feele.

column2: Yeeld thee, Lord Percy, Douglas sayd "In faith I will thee bringe, Where thou shalt high advanced bee By James our Scottish king.
column3: Yeeld thee, Lord Percy, Douglas sayd "In faith I will thee bringe, Where thou shalt high advanced bee By james our Scottish king.

column2: Thy ransom I will freely give, And thus report of thee, Thou art the most couragious knight That ever I did see.
column3: Thy ransom I will freely give, And thus report of thee, Thou art the most couragious knight That ever I did see.

column2: Noe, Douglas, quoth Erle Percy then, "Thy proffer I doe scorne I will not yeelde to any Scott, That ever yett was borne."
column3: Noe, Douglas, quoth Erle Percy then, "Thy proffer I doe scorne I will not yeelde to any Scott, That ever yett was borne."

column2: With that, there came an arrow keene Out of an English bow, Which struck Erle Douglas to the heart, A deepe and deadlye blow:
column3: With that, there came an arrow keene Out of an English bow, Which struck Erle Douglas to the heart, A deepe and deadlye blow:

column2: Who never spake more words than these, "Fight on, my merry men all; For why, my life is at an end: Lord Percy sees my fall."
column3: Who never spake more words than these, "Fight on, my merry men all; For why, my life is at an end: Lord Percy sees my fall."

column2: Then leaving liffe, Erle Percy tooke The dead man by the hand; And said, "Erle Douglas, for thy life Wold I had lost my land!
column3: Then leaving liffe, Erle Percy tooke The dead man by the hand; And said, "Erle Douglas, for thy life Wold I had lost my land!

column2: O Christ! my verry hart doth bleed With sorrow for thy sake; For sure, a more renowned knight Mischance cold never take.
column3: O Christ! my verry hart doth bleed With sorrow for thy sake; For sure, a more renowned knight Mischance cold never take.

column2: A knight amongst the Scotts there was, Which saw Erle Douglas dye, Who streight in wrath did vow revenge Upon the Lord Percye;
column3: A knight amongst the Scotts there was, Which saw Erle Douglas dye, Who streight in wrath did vow revenge Upon the Lord Percye;

column2: Sir Hugh Mountgomerye was he call'd, Who, with a spere most bright, Well-mounted on a gallant steed, Ran fiercely through the fight;
column3: Sir Hugh Mountgomerye was he call'd, Who, with a spere most bright, Well mounted on a gallant steed, Ran fiercely through the fight;

column2: And past the English archers all, Without all dread or feare, And through Earl Percyes body then He thrust his hatefull spere
column3: And past the English archers all, Without all dread or feare, And through Earl Percyes body then He thrust his hatefull spere

column2: With such a vehement force and might He did his body gore, The speare ran through the other side A large cloth-yard, and more.
column3: With such a vehement force and might He did his body gore, The speare ran through the other side A large cloth yard, and more.

column2: So thus did both these nobles dye, Whose courage none could staine; An English archer then perceiv'd The noble erle was slaine.
column3: So thus did both these nobles dye, Whose courage none could staine; An English archer then perceiv'd The noble erle was slaine.

column2: He had a bow bent in his hand, Made of a trusty tree; An arrow of a cloth-yard long Up to the head drew hee.
column3: He had a bow bent in his hand, Made of a trusty tree; An arrow of a cloth yard long Up to the head drew hee.

column2: Against Sir Hugh Mountgomerye, So right the shaft he sett, The grey goose-wing that was thereon In his harts bloode was wett.
column3: Against Sir Hugh Mountgomerye, So right the shaft he sett, The grey goose wing that was thereon In his harts bloode was wett.

column2: This fight did last from breake of day Till setting of the sun; For when they rung the evening bell, The battel scarce was done.
column3: This fight did last from breake of day Till setting of the sun; For when they rung the evening bell, The battel scarce was done.

column2: With stout Erle Percy, there was slaine, Sir John of Egerton, Sir Robert Ratcliff, and Sir John, Sir James, that bold Bar n.
column3: With stout Erle Percy, there was slaine, Sir john of Egerton, Sir Robert Ratcliff, and Sir john, Sir james, that bold Bar n.

column2: And with Sir George and stout Sir James, Both knights of good account, Good Sir Ralph Rabby there was slaine, Whose prowesse did surmount.
column3: And with Sir George and stout Sir james, Both knights of good account, Good Sir Ralph Rabby there was slaine, Whose prowesse did surmount.

column2: For Witherington needs must I wayle, As one in doleful dumpes; For when his legs were smitten off, He fought upon his stumpes.
column3: For Witherington needs must I wayle, As one in doleful dumpes; For when his legs were smitten off, He fought upon his stumpes.

column2: And with Erle Douglas, there was slaine Sir Hugh Mountgomerye, Sir Charles Murray, that from the feeld One foote wold never flee.
column3: And with Erle Douglas, there was slaine Sir Hugh Mountgomerye, Sir Charles Murray, that from the feeld One foote wold never flee.

column2: Sir Charles Murray of Ratcliff, too, His sisters sonne was hee; Sir David Lamb, so well esteem'd, Yet saved cold not bee.
column3: Sir Charles Murray of Ratcliff, too, His sisters sonne was hee; Sir David Lamb, so well esteem'd, Yet saved cold not bee.

column2: And the Lord Maxwell in like case Did with Erle Douglas dye; Of twenty hundred Scottish speres, Scarce fifty-five did flye.
column3: And the Lord Maxwell in like case Did with Erle Douglas dye; Of twenty hundred Scottish speres, Scarce fifty five did flye.

column2: Of fifteen hundred Englishmen, Went home but fifty-three; The rest were slaine in Chevy-Chace, Under the greene wood tree.
column3: Of fifteen hundred Englishmen, Went home but fifty three; The rest were slaine in Chevy Chace, Under the greene wood tree.

column2: Next day did many widowes come, Their husbands to bewayle; They washt their wounds in brinish teares, But all wold not prevayle.
column3: Next day did many widowes come, Their husbands to bewayle; They washt their wounds in brinish teares, But all wold not prevayle.

column2: Theyr bodyes, bathed in purple blood, They bore with them away: They kist them dead a thousand times, Ere they were cladd in clay.
column3: Theyr bodyes, bathed in purple blood, They bore with them away: They kist them dead a thousand times, Ere they were cladd in clay.

column2: This newes was brought to Eddenborrow, Where Scotlands king did raigne, That brave Erle Douglas suddenlye Was with an arrow slaine.
column3: This newes was brought to Eddenborrow, Where Scotlands king did raigne, That brave Erle Douglas suddenlye Was with an arrow slaine.

column2: O heavy newes, King James did say; "Scottland can witnesse bee, I have not any captaine more Of such account as hee."
column3: O heavy newes, King james did say; "Scottland can witnesse bee, I have not any captaine more Of such account as hee."

column2: Like tydings to King Henry came, Within as short a space, That Percy of Northumberland Was slaine in Chevy-Chace.
column3: Like tydings to King Henry came, Within as short a space, That Percy of Northumberland Was slaine in Chevy Chace.

column2: Now God be with him, said our king, "Sith it will noe better bee; I trust I have, within my realme, Five hundred as good as hee.
column3: Now God be with him, said our king, "Sith it will noe better bee; I trust I have, within my realme, Five hundred as good as hee.

column2: Yett shall not Scotts nor Scotland say, But I will vengeance take, I'll be revenged on them all, For brave Erle Percyes sake.
column3: Yett shall not Scotts nor Scotland say, But I will vengeance take, I'll be revenged on them all, For brave Erle Percyes sake.

column2: This vow full well the king perform'd After, at Humbledowne; In one day, fifty knights were slayne, With lordes of great renowne.
column3: This vow full well the king perform'd After, at Humbledowne; In one day, fifty knights were slayne, With lordes of great renowne.

column2: And of the rest, of small account, Did many thousands dye: Thus endeth the hunting in Chevy-Chace, Made by the Erle Percy.
column3: And of the rest, of small account, Did many thousands dye: Thus endeth the hunting in Chevy Chace, Made by the Erle Percy.

column2: God save our king, and bless this land In plentye, joy, and peace; And grant henceforth, that foule debate 'Twixt noblemen may cease!
column3: God save our king, and bless this land In plentye, joy, and peace; And grant henceforth, that foule debate 'Twixt noblemen may cease!

column2: King Cophetua and the Beggar-Maid
column3: King Cophetua and the Beggar Maid

column2: I read that once in Affrica A princely wight did raine, Who had to name Cophetua, As poets they did faine. From natures lawes he did decline, For sure he was not of my minde, He cared not for women-kind But did them all disdaine. But marke what hapned on a day; As he out of his window lay, He saw a beggar all in gray. The which did cause his paine.
column3: I read that once in Affrica A princely wight did raine, Who had to name Cophetua, As poets they did faine. From natures lawes he did decline, For sure he was not of my minde, He cared not for women kind But did them all disdaine. But marke what hapned on a day; As he out of his window lay, He saw a beggar all in gray. The which did cause his paine.
